description:
Coxsackievirus A2 (CVA2) is a member of the Picornaviridae family, specifically belonging to the Enterovirus genus. It is a non-enveloped, positive-sense, single-stranded RNA virus.

CVA2 is primarily associated with causing hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD), a common childhood illness characterized by the development of small, painful blisters or ulcers on the hands, feet, and mouth. The virus is transmitted through direct contact with respiratory droplets, contaminated surfaces, or fecal-oral transmission.

The genome of CVA2 is approximately 7.4 kilobases in length and encodes a single polyprotein that is subsequently cleaved into structural and non-structural proteins. These proteins play crucial roles in viral replication, assembly, and host cell interactions.

Infection with CVA2 typically results in mild to moderate symptoms, including fever, sore throat, and the characteristic skin lesions. In some cases, more severe complications, such as neurological manifestations or myocarditis, may occur, particularly in young children or immunocompromised individuals.

Diagnosis of CVA2 infection is typically done through laboratory testing, such as RT-PCR or virus isolation from clinical samples. Prevention and control measures primarily focus on good hygiene practices, such as handwashing and disinfecting contaminated surfaces, as well as the development of effective vaccines or antiviral therapies to manage HFMD outbreaks.
